elements.html:
If the Client has not obtained a quote:

We would encourage you to share your fencing quote with your neighbour. You may like to include a letter outlining your proposal.

You may also consider submitting a NTF as early as possible and waiting 30 days for a response.

choices.text: We disagree over who who should pay what
We disagree on what type of fence to build
We disagree where to build the fence
The fence includes a retaining wall
One of us has caused damage to the fence

elements.name: disagreement_type
elements.title: Why do you and your neighbour disagree?

elements.html:
There is a disagreement on what type of fence to build

Fences are typically replaced like-for-like (ie. The same as what was there before) There is no 'standard' fence. Instead, people should consider what is normal for the area and what their individual requirements are. If you disagree over what type of fence to build, you should talk first to try coming to a solution.
elements.name: advice_type_of_fence

elements.html:
There is a disagreement on who should pay what

Generally, fences are shared 50/50, but there are some exceptions Fences are typically replaced like-for-like (ie. The same as what was there before) If one of you wants a more expensive fence, that person would usually pay the difference The only way you can force someone to do something is to bring a fencing action through the Magistrates' court. If you intend to do this, you should seek legal advice. If your neighbour can't afford a new fence, you may like to negotiate with them to work out a friendly solution. You could try mediation or coming to your own agreement.
elements.name: advice_cost

elements.html:
There is a retaining wall

Retaining walls are not covered by the Fences Act, so the general principles of fencing may not apply If one neighbour caused the need for a retaining wall (ie. Excavated at the property) then they would usually pay the full cost It may be best to try and negotiate with your neighbour to come to an agreement. You could try a private discussion or mediation. How much will a new retaining wall cost? Where could it be built? What happens if a retaining wall is not built?
elements.name: advice_retaining_wall

elements.html:
A party has damaged the fence

Generally, the party that damages the fence must pay the full cost for repair or replacement You should consider the pre-existing condition of the fence. For example, if the fence was old and required replacement anyway, the damage may not be the primary issue. It may be best to try and negotiate with your neighbour to come to an agreement. You could try a private discussion or mediation. You may like to submit a NTF along with details of what you expect the other party pay.
elements.name: advice_damage
boundary_survey
elements.title: Have you had a boundary survey conducted?

elements.html:
The Client has conducted a Boundary Survey

The Fences Act allows for "give and take" fences, which means fences that are built around obstacles (ie. Not in a straight line) Fences are typically replaced like-for-like (ie. The same as what was there before) If you or the neighbour wish to claim adverse possession, you should seek legal advice. Adverse Possession is a complex legal issue and the DSCV cannot provide advice around these disputes. If you don't agree where the fence should be built, you should attempt to negotiate first to reach a solution Why do you still disagree? Are there things that you can negotiate over?
elements.name: advice_boundary_survey

elements.html:
The Client has not conducted a boundary survey

Obtaining a professionals opinion through a boundary survey may help you reach an outcome You can submit a "Boundary Survey Notice" to your neighbour, which can help you split the costs of obtaining the quote once you've obtained it.
elements.name: advice_no_boundary_survey
ntf_submit
elements.title: Have you submitted a Notice to Fence?

elements.html:
Notice to Fence

A NTF is a formal fencing document that is contained within the Fences Act. The NTF formalises your proposal to have the fence repaired/replaced and gives your neigbour 30 days to respond. A copy is available from our website and should be submitted with at least one quote. There is no requirement to do so, but we recommend submitting this via Registered Post If your neighbour responds and agrees with your proposal, you may build the fence as agreed. If your neighbour responds and disagrees with your proposal, you will need to reach an agreement together or have a Magistrate decide for you. If your neighbour has not responded within 30 days then the Fences Act provides that you may build the fence and seek to recover costs from the neighbour through the Magistrates' Court. At any time you can consider mediation through the DSCV. Mediation is free, confidential and voluntary, and can help parties reach an agreement where they are having difficulty themselves.
elements.name: notice_to_fence

elements.html:
The Client has submitted a Notice to Fence and the neighbour has not responded in 30 days

If your neighbour has not responded within 30 days then the Fences Act provides that you may build the fence and seek to recover costs from the neighbour through the Magistrates' Court. You can still negotiate with your neighbour and it may be useful to try mediation.
elements.name: ntf_30_days_no_response

elements.html:
The Client has submitted a Notice to Fence, however it has not been 30 days

You need to give your neighbour time to respond to your proposal. This period is 30 days. If you have not heard from your neighbour within 30 days you may like to approach them for mediation.
elements.name: ntf_30_days_not_lapsed
